awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Integrating Risk and Resilience into Undergraduate Engineering Education Towards a Hazard-Resilient Built Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at the University of the District of Columbia (UDC) seeks to improve students' preparation and success towards an engineering career or an advanced degree by infusing interdisciplinary risk and resilience training into undergraduate engineering education, especially in civil engineering. Undergraduate students are involved in the project as researchers, and outreach activities to high school and community college students are part of the project.

This project has the objectives to: update the educational experiences in civil engineering and related STEM programs at UDC by integrating interdisciplinary knowledge and skills development in risk and resilience;  enrich the undergraduate research experiences through creation of an interdisciplinary summer research program for resilient built environment; and increase the enrollment and retention rate in engineering programs through engaging students and outreach to local high schools and community colleges. This project will contribute to a diverse engineering workforce in the area of built environment. It is expected that at least 600 students will be directly impacted by this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Targeted Infusion Project at the University of the District of Columbia (UDC) was aimed at training the next generation of engineers with interdisciplinary risk and resilience skills and improve the preparation and success of students, especially those from populations traditionally underrepresented in STEM disciplines for an engineering career to meet the increasing demand for managing hazard-resilient built environment. Under the support of this project, three interdisciplinary courses were successfully developed and implemented at UDC including: Introduction to Risk and Resilience in Engineering, Reliability and Optimization Methods in Engineering, and Sensing and Data Analytics for Infrastructure Systems. These courses have enriched the course offering at UDC and prepared the students for employment and advanced studies in the emerging field of risk and resilience. This project also provided valuable research training for undergraduate students at UDC and allowed UDC faculty and student to be actively involved in the research field of risk and resilience. The project facilitated the establishment of a successful engineering ambassador program that engaged over 20 student ambassadors from undergraduate programs of Civil Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences. The ambassadors have conducted more than 20 virtual outreach activities for students at local high schools and community colleges. In these outreach events, the ambassadors shared their UDC experience, delivered presentations about UDC activities and each of the engineering and computer science programs at UDC, and conducted various hands-on activities related to risk and resilience in engineering to engage students in the STEM fields. Three Summer Risk and Resilience Academy Workshops were offered to student participants from high schools and community colleges, which attracts students to the STEM fields and trains a diverse workforce for a hazard-resilient built environment. A guest lecture series was developed with guest speakers from federal government and other academic institutions to expose students to the recent development in the risk and resilience field. Most students supported by this project secured an industry position or received full scholarships for graduate study in the STEM fields prior to graduation.
